balancer which routes the request to one of the two Easy's you are using a Z stands for availability zones so you are
using two availability zones which are completely isolated and they they are
they have their own different failure zones so it's very unlikely that two aces will go together will have the same
problem at the same time so so you're using two availability zones you have a
web server in one of them and then you have a master database which is serving most of the
right requests and read requests and you have a standby which is ready to be big to become active whenever your master
database is a problem so for example if a interruption happens on one of your
master databases the slave which is the replica or slave will stand by I will
become active and your customers will start using it so ideally you don't have much interruption in this system even if
one is egos down you have the exactly same system running in there another easy so so this is a good good start for

important to know here is in the previous system we had two machines but they were only two how do we scale our
systems as our customers are using our website more so so this is another common thing we have something called
auto scaling and the thing is very common in cloud world these days your machines increase or decrease based on
how many customers are on your website at a given time so you can set up rules where you say if my machines are at a
level where ec2 on the ec2 that a percentage of CPU is more than let's say
a 70% start adding a machine because it's very likely that they will go into 100% which means some of the customers
will not be able to be served from this system so so these this is a system where you have a layer of multiple web
services web instances and they increase or decrease based on how your customers
are using the website how much traffic you have so typically you will see in the night your systems will shrink in
the day when you have a lot of traffic and customers using it your systems will expand one of the other thing to note
here is we have something called read replicas which we are using because relational databases
traditionally are a single machine which is taking care of everything so it's
very hard to scale relational databases so what the one of the ways which customers scale them is use read
replicas so you route your read traffic to all the replicas and most likely you
will have read traffic which is higher than right in most cases that's true and most of
the traffic is served by read replicas but some of the right traffic comes to your master which is the right right
database so so this is another pattern where companies have become slightly
better than the previous system now let's take it to one step further so
another thing which we have to see is so far we have used only web servers and
databases now this tier we are trying to use different services for what they do
the best so for example in this case we typically website will have some static

which is based on a key so you can use dynamo DB for them and finally some of
the read workload or write workload can be served from a cache so you can start
using a cache for some of those very low latency use cases so ultimately you will
have a very scalable system which is spanning across multiple availability zones and you're using the right

completely continuously gets deployed so as soon as the checking is done the code is a build is triggered and the software
is ready to be deployed but there's another one another concept called continuous delivery which means most of
the things in your pipeline are not happening automatically but you have some manual gates so most times before
releasing the production you will do some testing it could be a QA person checking whether everything is looking good it could be a button you click
saying only in the night the deployment should happen it shouldn't happen during day so you can have multiple checks
